Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A 13,000 mile dragon of earth and stone winds its way through
the countryside of China with a history almost as long
and serpentine as the structure. The Great Wall began as multiple walls
of rammed earth built by individual feudal states
during the Chunqiu period to protect against nomadic raiders
north of China and each other. When Emperor Qin Shi Huang
unified the states in 221 BCE, the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean
became natural barriers, but the mountains in the north
remained vulnerable to Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions. To defend against them, the Emperor expanded the small walls
built by his predecessors, connecting some and fortifying others. As the structures grew
from Lintao in the west to Liaodong in the east, they collectively became known
as The Long Wall. To accomplish this task, the Emperor enlisted soldiers
and commoners, not always voluntarily. Of the hundreds of thousands of builders
recorded during the Qin Dynasty, many were forcibly conscripted peasants and others were criminals
serving out sentences. Under the Han Dynasty,
the wall grew longer still, reaching 3700 miles, and spanning from Dunhuang
to the Bohai Sea. Forced labor continued
under the Han Emperor Han-Wudi , and the walls reputation grew
into a notorious place of suffering. Poems and legends of the time
told of laborers buried in nearby mass graves, or even within the wall itself. And while no human remains
have been found inside, grave pits do indicate
that many workers died from accidents, hunger and exhaustion. The wall was formidable
but not invincible. Both Genghis and his son Khublai Khan
managed to surmount the wall during the Mongol invasion
of the 13th Century. After the Ming dynasty
gained control in 1368, they began to refortify
and further consolidate the wall using bricks and stones from local kilns. Averaging 23 feet high and 21 feet wide, the walls 5500 miles
were punctuated by watchtowers. When raiders were sighted, fire and smoke signals traveled
between towers until reinforcements arrived. Small openings along the wall
let archers fire on invaders, while larger ones were used
to drop stones and more. But even this new and improved wall
was not enough. In 1644, northern Manchu clans
overthrew the Ming to establish the Qing dynasty, incorporating Mongolia as well, Thus, for the second time, China was ruled by the very people
the wall had tried to keep out. With the empire's borders
now extending beyond the Great Wall, the fortifications lost their purpose. And without regular reinforcement,
the wall fell into disrepair, rammed earth eroded, while brick and stone were plundered
for building materials. But its job wasn't finished. During World War II, China used sections for defense
against Japanese invasion, and some parts are still rumored
to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: The Great Wall is one long wall that spans 100,000 miles.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary purpose of the Great Wall of China when it was first built? Options: A. To protect against natural disasters, B. To unify the states of China, C. To protect against nomadic raiders, D. To showcase the emperor's power Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who unified the states of China in 221 BCE and expanded the Great Wall? Options: A. Emperor Han-Wudi, B. Emperor Qin Shi Huang, C. Genghis Khan, D. Khublai Khan Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the approximate length of the Great Wall during the Han Dynasty? Options: A. 1,000 miles, B. 3,700 miles, C. 5,500 miles, D. 13,000 miles Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the primary material used to build the Great Wall during the Ming Dynasty? Options: A. Rammed earth, B. Bricks and stones, C. Wood and bamboo, D. Metal and iron Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the purpose of the watchtowers along the Great Wall? Options: A. To provide shelter for soldiers, B. To store food and supplies, C. To send fire and smoke signals to alert of invaders, D. To display the emperor's wealth Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which dynasty overthrew the Ming Dynasty and established a new ruling power in China? Options: A. Qing Dynasty, B. Han Dynasty, C. Ming Dynasty, D. Yuan Dynasty Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the current main purpose of the Great Wall of China? Options: A. Military defense, B. Cultural significance, C. Economic development, D. Environmental conservation Correct Option: None
Question 8: In what year was the Great Wall granted UNESCO World Heritage Status? Options: A. 1987, B. 1997, C. 2007, D. 2017 Correct Option: None
Question 9: Is it true that the Great Wall of China is visible from space? Options: A. Yes, it is visible from the moon, B. Yes, it is visible from low Earth orbit, C. No, it is not visible from space, D. Only under certain conditions Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is the Great Wall of China deteriorating today? Options: A. Due to natural erosion, B. Due to lack of maintenance, C. Due to the influx of tourists, D. Due to military activities Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: Is it true that the Great Wall of China is visible from space? Options: A. Yes, it is visible from the moon, B. Yes, it is visible from low Earth orbit, C. No, it is not visible from space, D. Only under certain conditions.

Although the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the length of the Great Wall, the closest match in terms of question intent (true or false) and content (related to a common myth about the Great Wall) is Question 9.

is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3

**Transcript**:
A 13,000 mile dragon of earth and stone winds its way through
the countryside of China with a history almost as long
and serpentine as the structure. The Great Wall began as multiple walls
of rammed earth built by individual feudal states
during the Chunqiu period to protect against nomadic raiders
north of China and each other. When Emperor Qin Shi Huang
unified the states in 221 BCE, the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean
became natural barriers, but the mountains in the north
remained vulnerable to Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions. To defend against them, the Emperor expanded the small walls
built by his predecessors, connecting some and fortifying others. As the structures grew
from Lintao in the west to Liaodong in the east, they collectively became known
as The Long Wall. To accomplish this task, the Emperor enlisted soldiers
and commoners, not always voluntarily. Of the hundreds of thousands of builders
recorded during the Qin Dynasty, many were forcibly conscripted peasants and others were criminals
serving out sentences. Under the Han Dynasty,
the wall grew longer still, reaching 3700 miles, and spanning from Dunhuang
to the Bohai Sea. Forced labor continued
under the Han Emperor Han-Wudi , and the walls reputation grew
into a notorious place of suffering. Poems and legends of the time
told of laborers buried in nearby mass graves, or even within the wall itself. And while no human remains
have been found inside, grave pits do indicate
that many workers died from accidents, hunger and exhaustion. The wall was formidable
but not invincible. Both Genghis and his son Khublai Khan
managed to surmount the wall during the Mongol invasion
of the 13th Century. After the Ming dynasty
gained control in 1368, they began to refortify
and further consolidate the wall using bricks and stones from local kilns. Averaging 23 feet high and 21 feet wide, the walls 5500 miles
were punctuated by watchtowers. When raiders were sighted, fire and smoke signals traveled
between towers until reinforcements arrived. Small openings along the wall
let archers fire on invaders, while larger ones were used
to drop stones and more. But even this new and improved wall
was not enough. In 1644, northern Manchu clans
overthrew the Ming to establish the Qing dynasty, incorporating Mongolia as well, Thus, for the second time, China was ruled by the very people
the wall had tried to keep out. With the empire's borders
now extending beyond the Great Wall, the fortifications lost their purpose. And without regular reinforcement,
the wall fell into disrepair, rammed earth eroded, while brick and stone were plundered
for building materials. But its job wasn't finished. During World War II, China used sections for defense
against Japanese invasion, and some parts are still rumored
to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did soldiers communicate between watchtowers along the Great Wall?
Options: A. Smoke and fire signals, B. Hand gestures and gongs, C. Flag waving and horns
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: Who unified the states of China in 221 BCE and expanded the Great Wall? Options: A. Emperor Han-Wudi, B. Emperor Qin Shi Huang, C. Genghis Khan, D. Khublai Khan Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the approximate length of the Great Wall during the Han Dynasty? Options: A. 1,000 miles, B. 3,700 miles, C. 5,500 miles, D. 13,000 miles Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the primary material used to build the Great Wall during the Ming Dynasty? Options: A. Rammed earth, B. Bricks and stones, C. Wood and bamboo, D. Metal and iron Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the purpose of the watchtowers along the Great Wall? Options: A. To provide shelter for soldiers, B. To store food and supplies, C. To send fire and smoke signals to alert of invaders, D. To display the emperor's wealth Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which dynasty overthrew the Ming Dynasty and established a new ruling power in China? Options: A. Qing Dynasty, B. Han Dynasty, C. Ming Dynasty, D. Yuan Dynasty Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the current main purpose of the Great Wall of China? Options: A. Military defense, B. Cultural significance, C. Economic development, D. Environmental conservation Correct Option: None
Question 8: In what year was the Great Wall granted UNESCO World Heritage Status? Options: A. 1987, B. 1997, C. 2007, D. 2017 Correct Option: None
Question 9: Is it true that the Great Wall of China is visible from space? Options: A. Yes, it is visible from the moon, B. Yes, it is visible from low Earth orbit, C. No, it is not visible from space, D. Only under certain conditions Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is the Great Wall of China deteriorating today? Options: A. Due to natural erosion, B. Due to lack of maintenance, C. Due to the influx of tourists, D. Due to military activities Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What was the purpose of the watchtowers along the Great Wall? 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the method of communication between watchtowers. Although the generated MCQ does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, option C of Question 5 mentions sending fire and smoke signals to alert of invaders, which aligns with the correct option of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4

**Transcript**:
A 13,000 mile dragon of earth and stone winds its way through
the countryside of China with a history almost as long
and serpentine as the structure. The Great Wall began as multiple walls
of rammed earth built by individual feudal states
during the Chunqiu period to protect against nomadic raiders
north of China and each other. When Emperor Qin Shi Huang
unified the states in 221 BCE, the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean
became natural barriers, but the mountains in the north
remained vulnerable to Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions. To defend against them, the Emperor expanded the small walls
built by his predecessors, connecting some and fortifying others. As the structures grew
from Lintao in the west to Liaodong in the east, they collectively became known
as The Long Wall. To accomplish this task, the Emperor enlisted soldiers
and commoners, not always voluntarily. Of the hundreds of thousands of builders
recorded during the Qin Dynasty, many were forcibly conscripted peasants and others were criminals
serving out sentences. Under the Han Dynasty,
the wall grew longer still, reaching 3700 miles, and spanning from Dunhuang
to the Bohai Sea. Forced labor continued
under the Han Emperor Han-Wudi , and the walls reputation grew
into a notorious place of suffering. Poems and legends of the time
told of laborers buried in nearby mass graves, or even within the wall itself. And while no human remains
have been found inside, grave pits do indicate
that many workers died from accidents, hunger and exhaustion. The wall was formidable
but not invincible. Both Genghis and his son Khublai Khan
managed to surmount the wall during the Mongol invasion
of the 13th Century. After the Ming dynasty
gained control in 1368, they began to refortify
and further consolidate the wall using bricks and stones from local kilns. Averaging 23 feet high and 21 feet wide, the walls 5500 miles
were punctuated by watchtowers. When raiders were sighted, fire and smoke signals traveled
between towers until reinforcements arrived. Small openings along the wall
let archers fire on invaders, while larger ones were used
to drop stones and more. But even this new and improved wall
was not enough. In 1644, northern Manchu clans
overthrew the Ming to establish the Qing dynasty, incorporating Mongolia as well, Thus, for the second time, China was ruled by the very people
the wall had tried to keep out. With the empire's borders
now extending beyond the Great Wall, the fortifications lost their purpose. And without regular reinforcement,
the wall fell into disrepair, rammed earth eroded, while brick and stone were plundered
for building materials. But its job wasn't finished. During World War II, China used sections for defense
against Japanese invasion, and some parts are still rumored
to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

Options: A. Terracotta, B. Gravel and sand, C. Rammed earth and bricks made in kilns
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive
or intensive pronoun. So what does that reveal about
where each word belongs? Let's start with the difference
between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish
subjects from objects, you can figure out what belongs where. And when you encounter 
a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted
for "me" and "I" because it seems more impressive. "Please tell Jack or myself" 
may sound elegant, but in fact, "me" 
is the right pronoun here. So where should you use "myself"? In its function as a reflexive pronoun, "myself" only works 
if it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I." "I consider myself the most important
pronoun at this year's party." "Myself" can also add emphasis
as an intensive pronoun. "I, myself, have heard others agree." The sentence works without it, but that extra pronoun gives it oomph. To check if "myself" belongs 
in a sentence, simply ensure that there's also an "I"
that it's reflecting or intensifying. So that's "me," "myself," and "I," ever ready to represent 
you, yourself, and you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The pronoun 'I' is:
Options: A. A reflexive pronoun, B. An adjective pronoun, C. An objective pronoun, D. A subject pronoun
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Reflexive pronoun, C. Subject pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 2: In the sentence "She danced around me," what is the function of the word "me"? Options: A. Subject of the sentence, B. Object of the verb, C. Object of a preposition, D. Reflexive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the main difference between subject and object in a sentence? Options: A. The subject is the word that is acted upon, and the object is the actor., B. The subject is the actor, and the object is the word that is acted upon., C. The subject is always a noun, and the object is always a verb., D. The subject is always a verb, and the object is always a noun. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following languages has different forms for nouns to distinguish subjects from objects? Options: A. English, B. Latin, C. Russian, D. Both B and C Correct Option: None
Question 5: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a complicated sentence? Options: A. By looking at the verb conjugation, B. By counting the number of subjects and objects, C. By temporarily eliminating the other person and distinguishing subject from object, D. By using a dictionary Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct? Options: A. Me heard gossip., B. I heard gossip., C. Myself heard gossip., D. Yourself heard gossip. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the function of "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"? Options: A. Subject pronoun, B. Object pronoun, C. Reflexive pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 8: When can "myself" be used as an intensive pronoun? Options: A. When it is the subject of the sentence, B. When it is the object of the sentence, C. When it adds emphasis to the sentence, D. When it is used as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 9: How can you check if "myself" belongs in a sentence? Options: A. By looking at the verb conjugation, B. By counting the number of subjects and objects, C. By ensuring that there is also an "I" that it is reflecting or intensifying, D. By using a dictionary Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding the use of "me," "myself," and "I"? Options: A. They can be used interchangeably in any sentence., B. They have specific roles in a sentence and should be used accordingly., C. They are only used in formal writing., D. They are only used in informal writing. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Reflexive pronoun, C. Subject pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun.

Although the correct option is not explicitly stated in the generated MCQ, the question content and options are similar to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the type of pronoun 'I' is, and the correct option is D. A subject pronoun. Similarly, the generated MCQ asks about the type of pronoun "I" is in a sentence, and option C is "Subject pronoun", which is the correct classification according to the transcript.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2

Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive

between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish

a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not directly ask about the type of pronoun 'me' is, it does ask about the function of 'me' in a sentence, which is closely related to the ground truth MCQ. In the transcript, it is mentioned that 'me' is an object pronoun, and in the given sentence "She danced around me," 'me' is the object of a preposition, which further supports the idea that 'me' is an object pronoun.

However, a more direct match can be found in Question 7, where it asks about the function of 'myself', but one of the options is "B. Object pronoun". If there was a similar question with 'me' instead of 'myself', that would be the perfect match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive
or intensive pronoun. So what does that reveal about
where each word belongs? Let's start with the difference
between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish
subjects from objects, you can figure out what belongs where. And when you encounter 
a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted
for "me" and "I" because it seems more impressive. "Please tell Jack or myself" 
may sound elegant, but in fact, "me" 
is the right pronoun here. So where should you use "myself"? In its function as a reflexive pronoun, "myself" only works 
if it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I." "I consider myself the most important
pronoun at this year's party." "Myself" can also add emphasis
as an intensive pronoun. "I, myself, have heard others agree." The sentence works without it, but that extra pronoun gives it oomph. To check if "myself" belongs 
in a sentence, simply ensure that there's also an "I"
that it's reflecting or intensifying. So that's "me," "myself," and "I," ever ready to represent 
you, yourself, and you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 'Myself' can be an intensive pronoun and its job in that role is to:
Options: A. Create emphasis in a sentence, B. Refer back to another pronoun, C. Intensify the language, D. Make the pronouns clearer
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Reflexive pronoun, C. Subject pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 2: In the sentence "She danced around me," what is the function of the word "me"? Options: A. Subject of the sentence, B. Object of the verb, C. Object of a preposition, D. Reflexive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the main difference between subject and object in a sentence? Options: A. The subject is the word that is acted upon, and the object is the actor., B. The subject is the actor, and the object is the word that is acted upon., C. The subject is always a noun, and the object is always a verb., D. The subject is always a verb, and the object is always a noun. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following languages has different forms for nouns to distinguish subjects from objects? Options: A. English, B. Latin, C. Russian, D. Both B and C Correct Option: None
Question 5: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a complicated sentence? Options: A. By looking at the verb conjugation, B. By counting the number of subjects and objects, C. By temporarily eliminating the other person and distinguishing subject from object, D. By using a dictionary Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct? Options: A. Me heard gossip., B. I heard gossip., C. Myself heard gossip., D. Yourself heard gossip. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the function of "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"? Options: A. Subject pronoun, B. Object pronoun, C. Reflexive pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 8: When can "myself" be used as an intensive pronoun? Options: A. When it is the subject of the sentence, B. When it is the object of the sentence, C. When it adds emphasis to the sentence, D. When it is used as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: None
Question 9: How can you check if "myself" belongs in a sentence? Options: A. By looking at the verb conjugation, B. By counting the number of subjects and objects, C. By ensuring that there is also an "I" that it is reflecting or intensifying, D. By using a dictionary Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding the use of "me," "myself," and "I"? Options: A. They can be used interchangeably in any sentence., B. They have specific roles in a sentence and should be used accordingly., C. They are only used in formal writing., D. They are only used in informal writing. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive
or intensive pronoun. So what does that reveal about
where each word belongs? Let's start with the difference
between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish
subjects from objects, you can figure out what belongs where. And when you encounter 
a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted
for "me" and "I" because it seems more impressive. "Please tell Jack or myself" 
may sound elegant, but in fact, "me" 
is the right pronoun here. So where should you use "myself"? In its function as a reflexive pronoun, "myself" only works 
if it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I." "I consider myself the most important
pronoun at this year's party." "Myself" can also add emphasis
as an intensive pronoun. "I, myself, have heard others agree." The sentence works without it, but that extra pronoun gives it oomph. To check if "myself" belongs 
in a sentence, simply ensure that there's also an "I"
that it's reflecting or intensifying. So that's "me," "myself," and "I," ever ready to represent 
you, yourself, and you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a sentence:
Options: A. Objects and subjects are interchangeable, B. Objects are superior to subjects, C. Objects do the acting, D. Subjects act upon objects
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells
called chromatophores to create patterns on their skin
that act as camouflage or warnings to rivals. Honeybees perform complex dances to let other bees know the location
and quality of a food source. All of these animals have impressive
communication systems, but do they have language? To answer that question, we can look at four specific qualities
that are often associated with language: discreteness, grammar, productivity, and displacement. Discreteness means that there is a set
of individual units, such as sounds or words, that can be combined
to communicate new ideas, like a set of refrigerator poetry magnets
you can rearrange to create different phrases. Grammar provides a system of rules that tells you how to combine 
those individual units. Productivity is the ability 
to use language to create an infinite number of messages. And displacement is the ability 
to talk about things that aren't right in front of you, such as past, future, or fictional events. So, does animal communication exhibit 
any of these qualities? For crabs and cuttlefish, 
the answer is no. They don't combine their signals 
in creative ways. Those signals also don't have to be 
in a grammatical order, and they only communicate 
current conditions, like, "I am healthy," 
or "I am poisonous." But some animals actually do display
some of these properties. Bees use the moves, angle, duration,
and intensity of their waggle dance to describe the location and richness
of a food source. That source is outside the hive, so they exhibit the property 
of displacement. They share that language trait
with prairie dogs, which live in towns of thousands, and are hunted by coyotes, hawks,
badgers, snakes, and humans. Their alarms calls indicate
the predator's size, shape, speed, and, even for human predators,
what the person is wearing and if he's carrying a gun. Great apes, like chimps and gorillas,
are great communicators, too. Some have even learned 
a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Discreteness is one characteristic of human language. Discreteness means:
Options: A. People can talk about topics in the past, in the future, or things not immediately present either temporally or physically, B. People can combine the units of their language (sounds, words, signs) to create, communicate and understand new ideas., C. People use discretion or tact when talking so as to not offend the person or people they are talking to, D. People talk about imaginary or abstract topics, such as "Liberty" and "Love"
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is an example of how crabs communicate with each other? Options: A. Through complex dances, B. By waving their claws, C. Using pigmented skin cells, D. Through vocalizations Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the term for the ability to use language to create an infinite number of messages? Options: A. Discreteness, B. Grammar, C. Productivity, D. Displacement Correct Option: None
Question 3: Which of the following animals has been observed using a modified sign language to communicate? Options: A. Prairie dogs, B. Great apes, C. Dolphins, D. Honeybees Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the term for the ability to talk about things that aren't right in front of you, such as past, future, or fictional events? Options: A. Discreteness, B. Grammar, C. Productivity, D. Displacement Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which animal has been observed using whistles to identify age, location, names, and gender? Options: A. Dolphins, B. Prairie dogs, C. Great apes, D. Honeybees Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the main difference between human language and animal communication, according to the transcript? Options: A. Human language is more complex, B. Animal communication is more limited in its topics of conversation, C. Human language has a powerful combination of grammar and productivity, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which of the following is an example of discreteness in animal communication? Options: A. A chimpanzee combining multiple signs into original phrases, B. A prairie dog's alarm call indicating the predator's size and shape, C. A honeybee's waggle dance describing the location and richness of a food source, D. A crab waving its claws to signal its health Correct Option: None
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why animal communication systems do not qualify as language? Options: A. They lack grammar, B. They lack productivity, C. They lack displacement, D. They do not display all four qualities of language Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which animal has been observed referring to a beloved kitten that had died, displaying displacement? Options: A. Coco, a female gorilla, B. Washoe, a chimpanzee, C. A prairie dog, D. A dolphin Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is a possible conclusion that can be drawn from research on animal communication? Options: A. Human language and animal communication are entirely different, B. Human language and animal communication exist on a continuum, C. Animal communication is more complex than human language, D. Human language is the only form of true communication Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

Although the options and the question itself are not identical, the intent of Question 7 is closest to the ground truth MCQ. Question 7 asks for an example of discreteness in animal communication and provides an option (A) that describes a chimpanzee combining multiple signs into original phrases, which is similar to the correct option (B) in the ground truth MCQ that defines discreteness as the ability to combine units of language to create, communicate, and understand new ideas.

but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Displacement is a quality found in the communication of both honeybees and in humans. Displacement means:
Options: A. Both bees and humans are capable of discussing information that is not immediately present, B. Bees and humans can talk about abstract concepts or imaginary topics, C. Bees and humans follow grammatical principles when communicating, D. Bees and humans can rearrange individual units of their communication to communicate new ideas
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is an example of how crabs communicate with each other? Options: A. Through complex dances, B. By waving their claws, C. Using pigmented skin cells, D. Through vocalizations Correct Option: None

Animal communication is more limited in its topics of conversation, C. Human language has a powerful combination of grammar and productivity, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which of the following is an example of discreteness in animal communication? Options: A. A chimpanzee combining multiple signs into original phrases, B. A prairie dog's alarm call indicating the predator's size and shape, C. A honeybee's waggle dance describing the location and richness of a food source, D. A crab waving its claws to signal its health Correct Option: None

Question 10: According to the transcript, what is a possible conclusion that can be drawn from research on animal communication? Options: A. Human language and animal communication are entirely different, B. Human language and animal communication exist on a continuum, C. Animal communication is more complex than human language, D. Human language is the only form of true communication Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells
called chromatophores to create patterns on their skin
that act as camouflage or warnings to rivals. Honeybees perform complex dances to let other bees know the location
and quality of a food source. All of these animals have impressive
communication systems, but do they have language? To answer that question, we can look at four specific qualities
that are often associated with language: discreteness, grammar, productivity, and displacement. Discreteness means that there is a set
of individual units, such as sounds or words, that can be combined
to communicate new ideas, like a set of refrigerator poetry magnets
you can rearrange to create different phrases. Grammar provides a system of rules that tells you how to combine 
those individual units. Productivity is the ability 
to use language to create an infinite number of messages. And displacement is the ability 
to talk about things that aren't right in front of you, such as past, future, or fictional events. So, does animal communication exhibit 
any of these qualities? For crabs and cuttlefish, 
the answer is no. They don't combine their signals 
in creative ways. Those signals also don't have to be 
in a grammatical order, and they only communicate 
current conditions, like, "I am healthy," 
or "I am poisonous." But some animals actually do display
some of these properties. Bees use the moves, angle, duration,
and intensity of their waggle dance to describe the location and richness
of a food source. That source is outside the hive, so they exhibit the property 
of displacement. They share that language trait
with prairie dogs, which live in towns of thousands, and are hunted by coyotes, hawks,
badgers, snakes, and humans. Their alarms calls indicate
the predator's size, shape, speed, and, even for human predators,
what the person is wearing and if he's carrying a gun. Great apes, like chimps and gorillas,
are great communicators, too. Some have even learned 
a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Grammar:
Options: A. Refers to the rules of how to write a composition correctly, B. Has been evidenced in the natural communication of dolphins in the wild, C. Provides a system of rules that tell us how to combine the units of our language, D. Is a characteristic of all animal communication systems
Correct Option: C

A prairie dog's alarm call indicating the predator's size and shape, C. A honeybee's waggle dance describing the location and richness of a food source, D. A crab waving its claws to signal its health Correct Option: None

Question 10: According to the transcript, what is a possible conclusion that can be drawn from research on animal communication? Options: A. Human language is the only form of true communication Correct Option: None

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ exactly. A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about the definition of grammar.

All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells
called chromatophores to create patterns on their skin
that act as camouflage or warnings to rivals. Honeybees perform complex dances to let other bees know the location
and quality of a food source. All of these animals have impressive

badgers, snakes, and humans. Their alarms calls indicate
the predator's size, shape, speed, and, even for human predators,
what the person is wearing and if he's carrying a gun. Great apes, like chimps and gorillas,
are great communicators, too. Some have even learned 
a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the date of the first Olympics?
Options: A. 1000 BC, B. 776 BC, C. 1066 AD
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which year did the Olympic Games originate? Options: A. 720 BC, B. 776 BC, C. 391 AD, D. 1896 AD Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the initial event featured in the Ancient Greek Olympics for the first thirteen games? Options: A. Boxing, B. Chariot racing, C. The two hundred yard dash, D. Javelin throwing Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the local baker who became the first Olympic champion in 776 BC? Options: A. Orsippus of Megara, B. Coroebus, C. Theodosius, D. Zeus Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which literary work can you read about the Ancient Greek Olympic events in? Options: A. "The Odyssey", B. "The Aeneid", C. "The Iliad", D. Both B and C Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the event in which competitors wore a full suit of armor? Options: A. Pentathlon, B. Pankration, C. Footrace, D. Chariot racing Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the term "Olympiad" refer to? Options: A. A period of two years, B. A period of four years, C. A period of eight years, D. A period of twelve years Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why did the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius ban the Olympic Games in 391 AD? Options: A. Due to a lack of participants, B. Due to the violent nature of the games, C. Because they were considered pagan practices, D. Because they were too expensive to host Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the Olympic athlete who started the tradition of competing in the nude? Options: A. Coroebus, B. Orsippus of Megara, C. Theodosius, D. Zeus Correct Option: None
Question 9: In what year did the modern Olympic Games begin? Options: A. 776 BC, B. 391 AD, C. 1500 AD, D. 1896 AD Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the meaning of the Olympic motto "Citius, Altius, Fortius"? Options: A. Faster, Higher, Stronger, B. Slower, Lower, Weaker, C. Quicker, Taller, More agile, D. None of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "In which year did the Olympic Games originate?" 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the date of the first Olympics. The correct answer, 776 BC, is also present in the options of Question 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What ancient place name underlies the word Olympics?
Options: A. Olympus, B. Olbia, C. Olympia
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which year did the Olympic Games originate? Options: A. 720 BC, B. 776 BC, C. 391 AD, D. 1896 AD Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the initial event featured in the Ancient Greek Olympics for the first thirteen games? Options: A. Boxing, B. Chariot racing, C. The two hundred yard dash, D. Javelin throwing Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the local baker who became the first Olympic champion in 776 BC? Options: A. Orsippus of Megara, B. Coroebus, C. Theodosius, D. Zeus Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which literary work can you read about the Ancient Greek Olympic events in? Options: A. "The Odyssey", B. "The Aeneid", C. "The Iliad", D. Both B and C Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the event in which competitors wore a full suit of armor? Options: A. Pentathlon, B. Pankration, C. Footrace, D. Chariot racing Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the term "Olympiad" refer to? Options: A. A period of two years, B. A period of four years, C. A period of eight years, D. A period of twelve years Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why did the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius ban the Olympic Games in 391 AD? Options: A. Due to a lack of participants, B. Due to the violent nature of the games, C. Because they were considered pagan practices, D. Because they were too expensive to host Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the Olympic athlete who started the tradition of competing in the nude? Options: A. Coroebus, B. Orsippus of Megara, C. Theodosius, D. Zeus Correct Option: None
Question 9: In what year did the modern Olympic Games begin? Options: A. 776 BC, B. 391 AD, C. 1500 AD, D. 1896 AD Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the meaning of the Olympic motto "Citius, Altius, Fortius"? Options: A. Faster, Higher, Stronger, B. Slower, Lower, Weaker, C. Quicker, Taller, More agile, D. None of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is most similar.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 3

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

Options: A. Wrestling, B. Running, C. Jumping
Correct Option: B

Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

Options: A. Nero, B. Diocletian, C. Theodosius
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Taking that internship 
in a remote mountain lab might not have been the best idea. Pulling that lever with the skull symbol
just to see what it did probably wasn't so smart, either, but now is not the time for regrets because you need to get away
from these mutant zombies fast. With you are the janitor, 
the lab assistant, and the old professor. You've gotten a headstart,
but there's only one way to safety: across an old rope bridge
spanning a massive gorge. You can dash across in a minute, while the lab assistant takes two minutes. The janitor is a bit slower
and needs five minutes, and the professor takes
a whole ten minutes, holding onto the ropes 
every step of the way. By the professor's calculations, the zombies will catch up to you
in just over 17 minutes, so you only have that much time
to get everyone across and cut the ropes. Unfortunately, the bridge can only hold
two people at a time. To make matters worse, it's so dark out that you can barely see, and the old lantern you grabbed on
your way only illuminates a tiny area. Can you figure out a way
to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem 
like no matter what you do, you're just a minute or two short of time,
but there is a way. The key is to minimize the time wasted
by the two slowest people by having them cross together. And because you'll need to make
a couple of return trips with the lantern, you'll want to have the fastest people
available to do so. So, you and the lab assistant quickly
run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down 
for the old professor who keeps muttering that he probably shouldn't 
have given the zombies night vision. By the time they're across,
there are only four minutes left, and you're still stuck
on the wrong side of the bridge. But remember, the lab assistant
has been waiting on the other side, and she's the second fastest of the group. So she grabs the lantern 
from the professor and runs back across to you. Now with only two minutes left,
the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the slowest out of the four people in the riddle?
Options: A. You, B. The professor, C. The assistant, D. The janitor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main objective of the group in the given scenario? Options: A. To find the source of the zombies, B. To escape across the rope bridge before the zombies catch up, C. To find a cure for the zombies, D. To explore the remote mountain lab Correct Option: None
Question 2: How long does it take the lab assistant to cross the rope bridge? Options: A. 1 minute, B. 2 minutes, C. 5 minutes, D. 10 minutes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the constraint on the number of people who can cross the bridge at a time? Options: A. Only one person can cross at a time, B. Only two people can cross at a time, C. Only three people can cross at a time, D. There is no constraint on the number of people Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the time constraint for the group to escape across the bridge? Options: A. 10 minutes, B. 15 minutes, C. 17 minutes, D. 20 minutes Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the key strategy to minimize the time wasted by the two slowest people? Options: A. Have them cross separately, B. Have them cross together, C. Have them wait on the other side, D. Have them stay behind Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who are the two fastest people in the group? Options: A. You and the professor, B. You and the lab assistant, C. The lab assistant and the janitor, D. The professor and the janitor Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long does it take the professor and the janitor to cross the bridge together? Options: A. 5 minutes, B. 10 minutes, C. 12 minutes, D. 15 minutes Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the role of the lab assistant in the final crossing? Options: A. She stays on the other side and waits, B. She runs back across to you with the lantern, C. She helps the professor and the janitor cross, D. She cuts the ropes Correct Option: None
Question 9: How much time is left when the professor and the janitor finish crossing the bridge? Options: A. 2 minutes, B. 4 minutes, C. 6 minutes, D. 8 minutes Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the final action taken by the group to prevent the zombies from crossing the bridge? Options: A. They destroy the lantern, B. They cut the ropes and collapse the bridge, C. They build a barricade, D. They distract the zombies Correct Option: None

run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down 
for the old professor who keeps muttering that he probably shouldn't 
have given the zombies night vision. By the time they're across,
there are only four minutes left, and you're still stuck
on the wrong side of the bridge. But remember, the lab assistant
has been waiting on the other side, and she's the second fastest of the group. So she grabs the lantern 
from the professor and runs back across to you. Now with only two minutes left,
the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many people can the bridge hold at a time?
Options: A. 4, B. 3, C. 2, D. 1
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Taking that internship 
in a remote mountain lab might not have been the best idea. Pulling that lever with the skull symbol
just to see what it did probably wasn't so smart, either, but now is not the time for regrets because you need to get away
from these mutant zombies fast. With you are the janitor, 
the lab assistant, and the old professor. You've gotten a headstart,
but there's only one way to safety: across an old rope bridge
spanning a massive gorge. You can dash across in a minute, while the lab assistant takes two minutes. The janitor is a bit slower
and needs five minutes, and the professor takes
a whole ten minutes, holding onto the ropes 
every step of the way. By the professor's calculations, the zombies will catch up to you
in just over 17 minutes, so you only have that much time
to get everyone across and cut the ropes. Unfortunately, the bridge can only hold
two people at a time. To make matters worse, it's so dark out that you can barely see, and the old lantern you grabbed on
your way only illuminates a tiny area. Can you figure out a way
to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem 
like no matter what you do, you're just a minute or two short of time,
but there is a way. The key is to minimize the time wasted
by the two slowest people by having them cross together. And because you'll need to make
a couple of return trips with the lantern, you'll want to have the fastest people
available to do so. So, you and the lab assistant quickly
run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down 
for the old professor who keeps muttering that he probably shouldn't 
have given the zombies night vision. By the time they're across,
there are only four minutes left, and you're still stuck
on the wrong side of the bridge. But remember, the lab assistant
has been waiting on the other side, and she's the second fastest of the group. So she grabs the lantern 
from the professor and runs back across to you. Now with only two minutes left,
the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.

spanning a massive gorge. You can dash across in a minute, while the lab assistant takes two minutes. The janitor is a bit slower
and needs five minutes, and the professor takes
a whole ten minutes, holding onto the ropes 
every step of the way. By the professor's calculations, the zombies will catch up to you
in just over 17 minutes, so you only have that much time
to get everyone across and cut the ropes. Unfortunately, the bridge can only hold
two people at a time. To make matters worse, it's so dark out that you can barely see, and the old lantern you grabbed on
your way only illuminates a tiny area. Can you figure out a way
to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem 
like no matter what you do, you're just a minute or two short of time,

by the two slowest people by having them cross together. And because you'll need to make
a couple of return trips with the lantern, you'll want to have the fastest people
available to do so. So, you and the lab assistant quickly
run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down

the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.
